title: The Nethy Routes Repository
text: A selection of routes for the UMHC Nethy trip, ranging from easy bimbles to big Munro days.

title: The Nethy Routes Repository
text:
Overview
Routes are categorised according to whether they can be completed from the hut or require club transport.
This is not an exhaustive list of all routes that have been completed on previous Nethys, but a selection of the most popular.
For each route, there is information on:

approximate difficulty (easy / medium / difficult)
length
ascent
start location
the intended route (minimal detail)

A GPX download for each route is also provided.

title: The Nethy Routes Repository
text:
Safety
When deciding on your route, remember to consider:

the weather conditions
the snow conditions, both in terms of the difficulty of movement and navigation, but also the risk of avalanche
the experience and fitness of your group
what equipment might be needed (crampons, ice axes, group shelter, headtorches, first-aid kit etc)
the daylight hours available.




Challenging navigation on the return from Ben Macdhui (Nethy 2012/13)

title: With transport
text:
Routes requiring club transport
Select the route of interest in the layers panel to display them on the map.
Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook

title: With transport
text:
Cairn Gorm (via Fiacaill Ridge)



Heading to Cairngorm after the scramble up Fiacaill Ridge (Nethy 2018/19)


A short but challenging route up a Grade 1 summer scramble starting at the ski centre car park. If under time pressure, a descent can be made via Point 1141

Difficulty: Medium / Hard
Length: 9.2 km
Ascent: 744 m
Start: Ski Centre CP
Description: Ski Centre CP → along the Allt Coire an t-Sneachda → Fiacaill Ridge → over Stob Coire an t-Sneachda → contour and summit Cairngorm → descend north to the top ski station → descend to CP via Sron an Aonaich.

title: With transport
text:
Cairn Gorm (Northern Corries)



View across the Cairngorm plateau and the northern corries to Cairn Toul and Braeriach on one of those rare high-pressure days


A traverse around the edge of the northern corries (Coire an t-Sneachda, Coire an Lochain), be aware of cornices!

Difficulty: Medium
Length: 11 km
Ascent: 796 m
Start: Ski Centre CP
Description: Ski Centre CP → trend south-west towards Lurcher’s Crag → climb steeply to Cairn Lochan → ascend Stob Coire an t-Sneachda and follow the above described route.

title: With transport
text:
Ben Macdhui



Crossing the Cairngorm plateau on the return from Ben Macdhui, white-out conditions never far away (Nethy 2012/13)


A journey to Britain’s second highest mountain. A full day out, especially if combined with Cairngorm. Strong navigation skills a requirement

Difficulty: Medium / Hard
Length: 15.8 km
Ascent: 770 m
Start: Ski Centre CP
Description: Ski Centre CP → trend south-west towards Lurcher’s Crag → climb steeply to west of Cairn Lochan → bear south across the plateau to Ben Macdhui summit (trig point) → return via the outward route, or contour the northern corries and descend via Point 1141 or Cairngorm.

title: With transport
text:
Sgòr Gaoith



Heading into the Lairig Ghru, with a snow-clad Sgòr Gaoith in the background (Nethy 2013/14)


One of the easier Munro’s in the area (alongside Cairn Gorm). Worth it for the views down into Gleann Eaniach, the summit perched above the cliffs

Difficulty: Medium
Length: 13.8 km
Ascent: 839 m
Start: Glen Feshie
Description: Invereshie and Inshriach National Nature Reserve CP → follow the path south-east as it tracks above the Allt Ruadh → cross the Allt a’ Chrom-alltain → ascend east to Sgòr Gaoith → return via the outward route, or more ambitiously via Meall Buidhe and Geal-charn.

title: With transport
text:
Braeriach



Approaching the summit of Braeriach, Sgòr an Lochain Uaine in the background (Nethy 2013/14)


The third highest mountain in Britain. A remote summit and a long and challenging day, involving much ascent and re-ascent. Beautiful in the right conditions

Difficulty: Hard
Length: 21 km
Ascent: 1050 m
Start: Sugar Bowl CP
Description: Sugar Bowl CP → Chalamain Gap → Lairig Ghru → Sron na Lairige → Braeriach summit → return via the outward route.

title: With transport
text:
Geal-charn Mòr



Descending from Geal-charn Mòr on the Burma Road, the high Cairngorms in the background


A straightforward Corbett on the edge of Aviemore, climbed most simply via the Burma Road, supposedly constructed by prisoners of war during WWII.

Difficulty: Easy / Medium
Length: 10 km
Ascent: 570 m
Start: Lynwilg
Description: Lynwilg (free parking at the start of the Burma Road) → Burma Road to bealach → Geal-charn Mòr → return via the outward route or descent via path on west flank of Creag Chleannain.

title: With transport
text:
Craigellachie



Summit cairn of Craigellachie (Nethy 2023/24)


A short but steep outing from Aviemore. A good choice in poor weather or if limited time available

Difficulty: Easy
Length: ~5 km
Ascent: 300 m
Start: Aviemore
Description: Marked route - follow signs!

title: With transport
text:
Mullach Clach a’ Bhlàir



Climbing Coire Garbhiach on the ascent to Mullach Clach a’ Bhlàir on a “no-snow” Nethy (Nethy 2015/16)


An uninspiring Munro, but worth doing if no other alternatives are available. Limited topographic interest, but pleasant in Glen Feshie

Difficulty: Medium
Length: ~21 km
Ascent: 750 m
Start: Glen Feshie
Description: Auchlean → south along Glen Feshie → ascend Coire Caol → south across plateau to non-descript summit → return via the outbound route.

title: With transport
text:
Braeriach to Devil’s Point



Crossing the Braeriach massif to the Devil’s Point, the deep trough of the Lairig Ghru below (Nethy 2016/17)


A massive and memorable outing for Munro baggers, but only feasible with limited snow cover. Four Munros, remote walking, and a long slog back up the Lairig Ghru to finish

Difficulty: Very Hard
Length: 37 km
Ascent: 2100 m
Start: Sugar Bowl CP
Description: Sugar Bowl CP → Chalamain Gap → Sron na Lairige → Braeriach summit → Sgòr an Lochain Uaine → Cairn Toul → Devil’s Point → Corrour Bothy → Lairig Ghru and the Pools of Dee → Chalamain Gap → Sugar Bowl CP.

title: With transport
text:
A’ Chailleach



Summit of A’ Chailleach, rising above Newtonmore. Credit: Steve Roddie


The closest and finest Munro in the rarely visted Monadhliath

Difficulty: Easy / Medium
Length: 10 km
Ascent: 620 m
Start: Glen Banchor above Newtonmore
Description: Glen Banchor → along the Allt a’ Chaorainn → ascent the south flank of A’ Chailleach → return by the outbound route.

title: With transport
text:
Ord Bàn



Summit of Ord Bàn, adorned with a glacial erratic


A short outing up a diminutive summit but superb views of the Cairngorms and the Monadhliath, and an excellent outing when combined with a circuit of Loch an Eilein. The Strava heatmap useful for path finding

Difficulty: Easy
Length: 7 km
Ascent: 250 m
Start: Loch an Eilein (parking charge applies)
Description: Loch an Eilein CP → clockwise around the lake → take left fork at NH 8882 0740 → follow to deer fence → follow near side of deer fence north east (clear but small path) towards Ord Bàn summit, with one fence crossing → from summit, descent east on minor stalkers path to start

title: From the hut
text:
Routes from the YHA at Glenmore
Select the route of interest in the layers panel to display them on the map.
Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook

title: From the hut
text:
Meall a’ Bhuachaille



Scrambling on the Fiacaill Ridge, Meall a’ Bhuachaille behind (Nethy 2018/19)


A popular Corbett standing directly above the Youth Hostel. Here is a chance to experience the beauty and wildness of the Cairngorms without the length and remoteness of some of the Munro walks

Difficulty: Easy / Medium
Length: 8.5 km
Ascent: 543 m
Start: Glenmore Lodge
Description: Glenmore Lodge → Ryvoan Pass → west to Meall a’ Bhuachaille summit → west to bealach → descent via Coire Chondlaich

title: From the hut
text:
Meall a’ Bhuachaille to Craiggowrie



Early morning climbing to Coire an t-Sneachda, the Meall a’ Bhuachaille ridge behind (Nethy 2018/2019)


As above, but continuing along the undulating ridge to Craiggowrie. Great views to the high Cairngorms and west to the Monadhliath

Difficulty: Medium
Length: 16.3 km
Ascent: 768 m
Start: Glenmore Lodge
Description: Glenmore Lodge → Ryvoan Pass → west to Meall a’ Bhuachaille summit → west to bealach → Creagan Gorm → Craiggowrie → descent south-west to forest edge → forest tracks to Badaguish Outdoor Centre
GPX: Download

title: From the hut
text:
Bynack More



A snowy Ryvoan Bothy on the approach to Bynack More. Credit: Alex Roddie


Bynack More is a prominent Munro, the northeastern cornerstone of the Cairngorms. It lacks any grand corries but is a magnificent viewpoint for northeast Scotland.

Difficulty: Medium / Hard
Length: 22 km
Ascent: 860 m
Start: Glenmore Lodge
Description: Glenmore Lodge → Ryvoan Pass → River Nethy → Bynack More → Return by the outbound route or alternatively via Bynack Beg

title: From the hut
text:
The Chalamain Gap



Through the Chalamain Gap on the long approach to Braeriach (Nethy 2013/14)


A lower level walk to pass through the bouldery defile of the Chalamain Gap. Be cautious in winter conditions: a known avalanche hotspot

Difficulty: Medium
Length: 17 km
Ascent: 454 m
Start: Glenmore Lodge
Description: Glenmore Lodge → forest tracks to the Sugar Bowl car park → west to the Chalamain Gap → descent to Lairig Ghru path → north along the banks of the Allt Druidh → Rothiemurchus Lodge → Loch Morlich → Glenmore

title: From the hut
text:
Loch Morlich



Preparing for winter skills in Coire na Ciste on a wintry Nethy, a frozen Loch Morlich in the distance (Nethy 2022/23)


An easy flat walk on forest tracks around Loch Morlich, with the stunning backdrop of the often snow-clad peaks of the northern Cairngorms. Lots of possibilities to modify and extend the route - the shortest variant is ~6 km

Difficulty: Easy
Length: 6 km
Ascent: 26 m
Start: Glenmore Lodge
Description: Follow the signs!

title: From the hut
text:
Loch an Eilein



The outflow of Loch Gamnha, feeding into Loch an Eilein (Nethy 2023/24)


An easy undulating walk on forest tracks to reach the beautiful Loch an Eilein. If transport is available, the circuit of the loch is ~7 km (parking charge applies)

Difficulty: Medium
Length: 23.5 km
Ascent: 235 m
Start: Glenmore Lodge
Description: Many possible variations, one of which is: Glenmore Lodge → south side of Loch Morlich → Cairngorm Club footbridge → Lochan Deo → Loch an Eilein → Rothiemurchus → return via the Old Logging Way

title: With transport
text:
Monadhliath Munros



Carn Dearg, rising above Gleann Ballach. Credit: Steven Fallon


Tikcking off three of the Monadhliath Munros, A’ Chailleach, Carn Sgulain and Carn Dearg. A long, rough and remote outing

Difficulty: Hard
Length: 24.5 km
Ascent: 1035 m
Start: Glen Banchor above Newtonmore
Description: Glen Banchor → along the Allt a’ Chaorainn → ascent the south flank of A’ Chailleach → Carn Sgulain → very long plateau tramp south-west to Carn Dearg → north from the summit, then descent north-east into Gleann Ballach → finish on track following the Allt Fionndrigh.

title: With transport
text:
To Nethy Bridge



A walk down memory lane (for the Old Gits)


An easy walk on forest tracks to reach the original Nethy House, now a café. Transport needs to be organised for the return, or vica-versa if starting at Nethy Bridge

Difficulty: Easy
Length: 15.5 km
Ascent: 145 m
Start: Glenmore Lodge
Description: Glenmore Lodge → Ryvoan Bothy → Rynettin → Nethy Bridge → return via club transport or walk (+15 km)
